content.question:
Spheres <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, shown in the figure, are three identical conducting spheres that have been placed on top of insulating stands. Initially, Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> has a positive charge while spheres <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> are each electrically neutral. The spheres are far enough apart that they do not affect the charge distributions on each other. A student brings spheres into contact, two at a time, in the following order.

Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is moved and brought into contact with Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, then returned to its initial position.

Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is moved and brought into contact with Sphere <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, then returned to its initial position.

Sphere <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> is moved and brought into contact with Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, then returned to its initial position.
Which of the following correctly relates the final net charges <math alttext="Q sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="Q sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="Q sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, of the three spheres?

choices.label: <math alttext="Q sub 1 equals Q sub 2, which equals Q sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="Q sub 1 is greater than Q sub 2, which equals Q sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="Q sub 1 equals Q sub 3, which is greater than Q sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="Q sub 3 is greater than Q sub 1, which equals Q sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="Q sub 1 equals Q sub 3, which is greater than Q sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>
